c: Lifestyle medicine and health promotion

n.c: Students will identify a current and important health issue in their country, critically evaluate domestic and international response to the issue (including a review of recent policy), and provide evidence-informed recommendations to improve the situation. The final report should be approximately 2500 words (excluding a reference list and any appendices). The report should include a detailed review of the relevant literature and policy documents.

Reading insight journal. Students should identify 6 journal articles that relate to the key course themes, particularly those relevant to Japan. After reading each paper, students should prepare a 1⁄2- to 1-page summary with the following headings: Research focus or aims; Major finding(s); Research limitations; Student questions and comments.

Oral presentation (10 minutes) on a hot-topic in Japanese public health. Students must clearly identify the problem, its significance, any interventions and evidence-informed recommendations for further action.

b: Healthy cities: urban spaces for active living
c: Healthy cities: urban spaces for active living

n.c: Building on the key findings from their earlier research (as outlined in the presentation above), students will provide an evidence (literature and policy) informed report that provides detailed and original solutions to address the urban environmental issue that they have identified in Tokyo. The report should include the following sections: background and summary of previous findings (from their presentation), overview of the relevant literature concerning the problem (e.g. health implications, international examples, effective interventions etc.), evidence-informed recommendations/solutions, potential threats to implementation, and conclusion. There is a 2,500 word limit (excluding references and tables). References should be cited in APA format with appropriate in-text citation.
Completion of weekly class reading summaries and in-class reviews and discussion. Students are expected to attend at least 70% of all classes (11/15 in practice) in order to pass the course.

Students will conduct a basic environmental assessment/audit that combines a multi-method approach within Tokyo (preferably near to the Waseda campus or the students’ place of residence). This can include a combination of map data, observational data (photography) and the use of a valid and reliable audit instrument. Each Topics should address one of the following areas: 1) Parks and open space access 2) pedestrian and cycling infrastructure, 3) the food environment, 4) the alcohol/tobacco environment, or 5) another topic approved by Dr Annear. Students will present their argument, procedures and main findings in a 15-20 minute class presentation during weeks 6.
